an7.70:4.1: Then as Venerable Sāriputta was in private solitude this thought came to his mind:
an7.70:4.2: “What should a mendicant honor and respect and live supported by, to give up the unwholesome and develop the wholesome?”
an7.70:4.4: “A mendicant should honor and respect and live supported by the Teacher …
an7.70:4.10: A mendicant should honor and respect and live supported by hospitality, to give up the unwholesome and develop the wholesome.”
an7.70:5.2: “These qualities are pure and bright in me. Why don’t I go and tell them to the Buddha?
an7.70:5.3: Then these qualities will not only be purified in me, but will be better known as purified.
an7.70:5.4: Suppose a man were to acquire a gold ornament, pure and bright.
an7.70:5.6: ‘My gold ornament is pure and bright. Why don’t I take it to show the smiths?
an7.70:5.7: Then it will not only be purified, but will be better known as purified.’
an7.70:5.8: In the same way, these qualities are pure and bright in me. Why don’t I go and tell them to the Buddha?
an7.70:5.9: Then these qualities will not only be purified in me, but will be better known as purified.”
an7.70:6.1: Then in the late afternoon, Sāriputta came out of solitude and went to the Buddha.
an7.70:6.2: He bowed, sat down to one side,
an7.70:6.3: and told the Buddha of his thoughts while on retreat.
an7.70:8.2: A mendicant should honor and respect and live supported by the Teacher, to give up the unwholesome and develop the wholesome.
an7.70:8.3: A mendicant should honor and respect and live supported by the teaching …
an7.70:8.8: A mendicant should honor and respect and live supported by hospitality, to give up the unwholesome and develop the wholesome.”
an7.70:9.1: When he said this, Venerable Sāriputta said to the Buddha:
an7.70:9.2: “Sir, this is how I understand the detailed meaning of the Buddha’s brief statement.
an7.70:9.3: It’s quite impossible that a mendicant who doesn’t respect the Teacher could respect the teaching.
an7.70:9.4: A mendicant who disrespects the Teacher disrespects the teaching.
an7.70:10.1: It’s quite impossible that a mendicant who doesn’t respect the Teacher and the teaching could respect the Saṅgha.
an7.70:10.2: A mendicant who disrespects the Teacher and the teaching disrespects the Saṅgha.
an7.70:11.1: It’s quite impossible that a mendicant who doesn’t respect the Teacher, the  teaching, and the Saṅgha could respect the training.
an7.70:11.2: A mendicant who disrespects the Teacher, the teaching, and the Saṅgha disrespects the training.
an7.70:12.1: It’s quite impossible that a mendicant who doesn’t respect the Teacher, the  teaching, the Saṅgha, and the training could respect samādhi.
an7.70:12.2: A mendicant who disrespects the Teacher, the teaching, the Saṅgha, and the training disrespects samādhi.
an7.70:13.1: It’s quite impossible that a mendicant who doesn’t respect the Teacher, the  teaching, the Saṅgha, the training, and samādhi could respect diligence.
an7.70:13.2: A mendicant who disrespects the Teacher, the teaching, the Saṅgha, the training, and samādhi disrespects diligence.
an7.70:14.1: It’s quite impossible that a mendicant who doesn’t respect the Teacher, the  teaching, the Saṅgha, the training, samādhi, and diligence could respect hospitality.
an7.70:14.2: A mendicant who disrespects the Teacher, the teaching, the Saṅgha, the training, samādhi, and diligence disrespects hospitality.
an7.70:15.1: It’s quite impossible that a mendicant who does respect the Teacher could disrespect the teaching. …
an7.70:16.3: A mendicant who respects the Teacher, the teaching, the Saṅgha, the training, samādhi, and diligence respects hospitality.
an7.70:17.1: It’s quite possible that a mendicant who respects the Teacher could respect teaching. …
an7.70:18.3: A mendicant who respects the Teacher, the teaching, the Saṅgha, the training, samādhi, and diligence respects hospitality.
an7.70:19.1: That’s how I understand the detailed meaning of the Buddha’s brief statement.”
an7.70:20.2: It’s good that you understand the detailed meaning of what I’ve said in brief like this.
an7.70:20.3: It’s quite impossible that a mendicant who doesn’t respect the Teacher could respect the teaching. …
an7.70:21.2: A mendicant who disrespects the Teacher, the teaching, the Saṅgha, the training, samādhi, and diligence disrespects hospitality.
an7.70:22.1: It’s quite impossible that a mendicant who does respect the Teacher could disrespect the teaching. …
an7.70:23.3: A mendicant who respects the Teacher, the teaching, the Saṅgha, the training, samādhi, and diligence respects hospitality.
an7.70:24.1: It’s quite possible that a mendicant who does respect the Teacher could respect the teaching. …
an7.70:25.3: A mendicant who respects the Teacher, the teaching, the Saṅgha, the training, samādhi, and diligence respects hospitality.
an7.70:26.1: This is how to understand the detailed meaning of what I said in brief.”
